attachments.title: PPL Bench: Creating a standard for benchmarking probabilistic programming languages
attachments.text: PPL Bench is an open-source, standardized benchmarking framework for measuring inference performance in probabilistic programming languages.
attachments.fallback: PPL Bench: Creating a standard for benchmarking probabilistic programming languages

messages.text: I am now convinced that the Markov kernel is the fundamental conceptional unit of functional probabilistic programming. So what is it‚Äôs equivalent in imperative code? A randomized instruction?

elements.text: I am now convinced that the Markov kernel is the fundamental conceptional unit of functional probabilistic programming. So what is it‚Äôs equivalent in imperative code? A randomized instruction?

messages.text: I think form this perspective functional and imperative are not so different. FP is a way of programming that makes code very easy to reason about, but it's not the only way. Imperative code that takes `f(x)` and returns `y` is like functional code that takes `f*(x, world1)` and returns `(y, world2)`. The biggest difference is a given "world" can only be referenced once, but this can be put in terms of linear logic. The Clean programming language, for example, is functional but handled IO in this way.

messages.text:
Oops I mean uniqueness typing, not quite the same as linear logic:
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniqueness_type>

attachments.title: Uniqueness type
attachments.text: In computing, a unique type guarantees that an object is used in a single-threaded way, with at most a single reference to it. If a value has a unique type, a function applied to it can be optimized to update the value in-place in the object code. Such in-place updates improve the efficiency of functional languages while maintaining referential transparency. Unique types can also be used to integrate functional and imperative programming.

messages.text:
My understanding of it (<@U6C937ENB> correct me if your take is different):
Probability distributions form a monad, so for any type `a` we can form `Prob a` (haskell notation), "probability distributions over `a`).

Monads can be described in terms of *Kleisli arrows*, which are just functions `a -> Prob b`.

As I understand it, a Markov kernel is just this, a function that takes a value and returns a distribution over values of some (generally different) type.

messages.text:
I've had some weirdness come up in Soss once in a while that traces back to named tuples being ordered.

<https://github.com/simonbyrne/KeywordDispatch.jl> has a nice trick here, basically sort the named tuple before passing to the call. For small named tuples that works great, but with a few levels of nesting there's a fair amount of overhead.

So the idea here is to instead just sort once, recursively, and then use that in all calls. I expect this will also allow a recursive merge to be faster, since we can walk linearly through both arguments.

I've had some weirdness come up in Soss once in a while that traces back to named tuples being ordered.

has a nice trick here, basically sort the named tuple before passing to the call. For small named tuples that works great, but with a few levels of nesting there's a fair amount of overhead.

So the idea here is to instead just sort once, recursively, and then use that in all calls. I expect this will also allow a recursive merge to be faster, since we can walk linearly through both arguments.

messages.text:
<@UDGT4PM41> <@U66G4838Q>  to really understand this i need a toy example of a classifier that doesn't satisfy expression (1) and a demonstration of what the ||-operator does to it to make expression (2) hold

a typo i noticed on page 3 right hand column two thirds of the way down:
> with P being uniform a uniform measure over that hypercube
page 4:
> However, this is a special case; for most distributional properties, most models do not possess a corresponding variable.
if a model is parameterized then fixing a distributional property is tantamount to constraining the parameters to take values in some subset _S_, right? and if the parameters themselves have Bayesian-style prior distributions then conditioning on the distributional property taking that fixed value is tantamount to truncating the support of the prior to just _S_, right? what am i missing? i mean, this is a pain to do in particular cases so if all Omega does is make it easy in general that's fantastic, but i don't think this is going beyond what can already be expressed in Bayesian probability theory/data analysis

if i'm right about that, then p-boxes are strictly more expressive since possibility theory is a generalization of probability theory (but i have yet to find myself reaching for that extra expressive power and am so far content being a Bayesian)

messages.text:
I like the approach. It‚Äôs 2nd order probability right? In UQ we call them 2nd order distributions (some people meta-distributions), and simulating them 2nd order Monte Carlo. They should definitely be considered in Probabilistic Programming, and also does fit into the Imprecise Probabilities picture, although some of my colleges would disagree and usually they‚Äôre not discussed in IP. Computations with them can be quite expensive, and correlations/dependencies can be troublesome. But they‚Äôre nonetheless a very flexible way to express uncertainty about a probability measure.

I would say:
‚Ä¢ Random sets: generic sets probability measures
‚Ä¢ P-boxes: cdf shaped random sets
‚Ä¢ Possibility distributions: consonant random sets
‚Ä¢ 2nd order distributions: probability measures which are distributions
I would consider it as an extension of Bayesian inference. You can calibrate for them with bayesian updating but you need to modify the likelihood using a stochastic distance metric:
<https://www.rpsonline.com.sg/proceedings/esrel2020/pdf/5520.pdf>
<https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0888327018304837?casa_token=88aISmlFIcwAAAAA:8oNovWKbMr4RDirEQ8zamR30gU5iAIHt6HKN34QXOfNOAJgrBzM4fAsu7KStGO5XM-iR1X608Y9D|https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0888327018304837?casa_token=88aISmlF[‚Ä¶]zamR30gU5iAIHt6HKN34QXOfNOAJgrBzM4fAsu7KStGO5XM-iR1X608Y9D>

attachments.title: The role of the Bhattacharyya distance in stochastic model updating
attachments.text: The Bhattacharyya distance is a stochastic measurement between two samples and taking into account their probability distributions. The objective of t‚Ä¶

elements.text:
I like the approach. It‚Äôs 2nd order probability right? In UQ we call them 2nd order distributions (some people meta-distributions), and simulating them 2nd order Monte Carlo. They should definitely be considered in Probabilistic Programming, and also does fit into the Imprecise Probabilities picture, although some of my colleges would disagree and usually they‚Äôre not discussed in IP. Computations with them can be quite expensive, and correlations/dependencies can be troublesome. But they‚Äôre nonetheless a very flexible way to express uncertainty about a probability measure.

I would say:
Random sets: generic sets probability measures
P-boxes: cdf shaped random sets
Possibility distributions: consonant random sets
2nd order distributions: probability measures which are distributions
I would consider it as an extension of Bayesian inference. You can calibrate for them with bayesian updating but you need to modify the likelihood using a stochastic distance metric:
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0888327018304837?casa_token=88aISmlF[‚Ä¶]zamR30gU5iAIHt6HKN34QXOfNOAJgrBzM4fAsu7KStGO5XM-iR1X608Y9D

<https://discourse.mc-stan.org/t/interface-to-stans-algorithms-from-c-and-beyond/20282>

On Twitter, I asked Ivan about using this to call Stan from Julia. His response:
> Yep, that's the plan! For now I'm going to try piping it through cppyy and PyCall and sometime later write direct Julia-C++ wrappers.

attachments.title: Interface to Stan's algorithms from C++ and beyond
attachments.text: Hello everyone! I wanted to share with you my work on trying to use Stan algorithms without Stan-Math and .stan files. Not relying on .stan files is relatively easy, just code up a header that looks similar to what stanc generates using stan::math::var in log_prob and done. Nothing much gained at this step. Stan-Math obviously intervenes into Stan a bit more deeply but luckily not so much. Stan is really a great example of modular development. I really enjoyed (and learned a lot) navigating t...
attachments.fallback: The Stan Forums: Interface to Stan's algorithms from C++ and beyond

elements.text: since you had mentioned Stan...
On Twitter, I asked Ivan about using this to call Stan from Julia. His response:
Yep, that's the plan! For now I'm going to try piping it through cppyy and PyCall and sometime later write direct Julia-C++ wrappers.

messages.text:
Does this seem like a fair test?
```Œº = randn(1000)
œÉ = rand(1000)
x = randn(1000)
y = randn(1000)

using BenchmarkTools
function time_normal(f)
    function go(f, Œº, œÉ, x, y)
        for i in eachindex(x)
            @inbounds y[i] = logdensity(f(Œº[i], œÉ[i]), x[i])
        end
    end

    @belapsed $go($f, $Œº, $œÉ, $x, $y)
end```
```julia> sŒºœÉ =  time_normal((Œº,œÉ) -> Dists.Normal(Œº,œÉ; check_args=false)) / time_normal((Œº,œÉ) -> Normal(Œº,œÉ))
1.3814563928873838

julia> sŒº1 =  time_normal((Œº,œÉ) -> Dists.Normal(Œº,1.0; check_args=false)) / time_normal((Œº,œÉ) -> Normal(Œº=Œº))
40.1426842474043

julia> s0œÉ =  time_normal((Œº,œÉ) -> Dists.Normal(0.0,œÉ; check_args=false)) / time_normal((Œº,œÉ) -> Normal(œÉ=œÉ))
1.4177335229966808

julia> s01 =  time_normal((Œº,œÉ) -> Dists.Normal()) / time_normal((Œº,œÉ) -> Normal())
42.33345406856929```
`s` is for "speedup" (that's good enough for me!)

messages.text:
I think Turing uses `FillArrays` a lot, right? Has anyone compared this with `MappedArrays`? I'm finding that to be much faster, which really surprises me. Not sure why that would be.
<https://github.com/cscherrer/MeasureTheory.jl/issues/52>

FillArrays
a lot, right? Has anyone compared this with
MappedArrays
? I'm finding that to be much faster, which really surprises me. Not sure why that would be.

messages.text:
My goal with the performance comparison was to compare times _as people actually use the code_. I appreciate the suggestions you made earlier, but with those caveats I think it's now a fair comparison.

Real fixes outside of Distributions.jl aren't possible, because the types are restricted in the structs themselves. I agree that a lot of this should really be fixed in Distributions itself. It seems to me packages like DistributionsAD come about because Distributions is so large and widely-used that even small changes require lots of negotiation, which slows down development.

> There's no good reason why Distributions couldn't be AD-friendly even without unnormalized densities.
Of course Distributions _could_ be AD-friendly. Lots of things could be improved. It seems a little bit like the state of R before Hadley Wickham came along. Sure, you could get things to work, but it usually felt find of like a patchwork.

Maybe that's what Distributions needs, corporate funding to fork the repo and smooth out all of the bumps. That would be great, but we don't currently have resources like that.

My goal with the performance comparison was to compare times
as people actually use the code

. I appreciate the suggestions you made earlier, but with those caveats I think it's now a fair comparison.

Real fixes outside of Distributions.jl aren't possible, because the types are restricted in the structs themselves. I agree that a lot of this should really be fixed in Distributions itself. It seems to me packages like DistributionsAD come about because Distributions is so large and widely-used that even small changes require lots of negotiation, which slows down development.
There's no good reason why Distributions couldn't be AD-friendly even without unnormalized densities.
Of course Distributions
could

be AD-friendly. Lots of things could be improved. It seems a little bit like the state of R before Hadley Wickham came along. Sure, you could get things to work, but it usually felt find of like a patchwork.

Maybe that's what Distributions needs, corporate funding to fork the repo and smooth out all of the bumps. That would be great, but we don't currently have resources like that.

messages.text: Currently ArviZ.jl only supports plotting using PyPlot.jl (and sort of bokeh). I think it will be much more useful to hook it into Julia's native plotting packages. Some thoughts on how to do this here, but I'm interested in suggestions from the community, especially from ArviZ.jl users.¬†<https://github.com/arviz-devs/ArviZ.jl/issues/108>

elements.text: Currently ArviZ.jl only supports plotting using PyPlot.jl (and sort of bokeh). I think it will be much more useful to hook it into Julia's native plotting packages. attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/vincefort|@vincefort>: Have you ever wondered whether isotropic Gaussian priors are good enough for your Bayesian neural network weights? They are often used in practice, but we find in our new paper (<https://arxiv.org/abs/2102.06571>) that they are indeed suboptimal! Details in thread. 1/13 <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EuVw9j2WYAMM-Qy.png>

messages.text:
Hi all,

Would it be useful for there to be a package implementing analytic variational inference? Using, for example, a factorised posterior of a full multivariate normal for model parameters and gamma for precision.
I suppose the use case for this would be very fast and accurate inference for small-ish models, potentially useful for exploratory analysis.

elements.text:
Hi all,

Would it be useful for there to be a package implementing analytic variational inference? Using, for example, a factorised posterior of a full multivariate normal for model parameters and gamma for precision.
I suppose the use case for this would be very fast and accurate inference for small-ish models, potentially useful for exploratory analysis.

More back-ends on the way @theogf we should come up with a nice way to incorporate callbacks so this works well with Turkie.jl @baggepinnen I think I had been stretching MonteCarloMeasurements.jl beyond its intended use. attachments.title: Stan General Meeting, Mar 04, 2021, 11 am EST
attachments.text: Here‚Äôs a short summary of what we talked about in the meeting. Jonah reported in about further MRP developments and that its almost ready to be tested by users he‚Äôs just working on some more testing and documentation. There were also some additions to Bayesplot that Aki had come up with that should be implemented soon. Charles mentioned working more on laplace with autodiff and that it‚Äôs still a little hard to work through. Also, we talked about the possibility of moving from Slack to other...

attachments.title: Infinite hierarchies and prior distributions
attachments.text: This paper introduces a way of constructing non-informative priors for Bayesian analysis, by taking a limit of priors arising from hierarchical constructions as the number of levels in the hierarchy converges to infinity. Results are proved showing that for location families, and other related cases, limits are often not dependent on the exact form of the increment distribution used.
